title: Seeding Structured Data by Default via Open Source Library Systems
segmentation: Well, it's great to see some familiar faces.
This is my first time at the SWC and it's been an amazing experience so far so.
Nice to see you all there.
First of all, I wanted to point out when we're talking about libraries.
I'm not talking about libraries of code, which is a common mistake.
When I first talked about this topic libraries.
These so back in 96 Nardino Day had talked about information seeking behaviors and they classify them generally as being other monitoring searches or planned searches or exploratory searches.

And when I read the Tim Berners Lee vision of the Semantic Web in 2001, Scientific American, it seems like there's a lot of overlap with the intelligent agents that would be carrying out the same sort of searches on behalf of their users.

And I also saw Parallels earlier this week at the question and answer over linked open Data Workshop that Christine and Andre put on, which was also reaffirming that there's a lot of synergy between Libra.
In the semantic web.
So when I talk about library systems, I'm talking about traditional library systems.
The less glamorous, less sexy, but still sort of the backbone of libraries.
Those things that have an inventory back end, which maybe a relational database sometimes is flat file, and they have a web catalog front end.
Generally these days to assist users and searching and retrieving resource is that the library has access to.
And typically these have machine readable cataloging Marc records as the unit for each one of the records that are described as well.
See Machine Readable is a little bit ironic for a name.
And libraries have been early technology adopters.
The first access for the Internet.
They jumped on board and provided telnet access to the catalogs for their for their systems.
Large libraries generally in the attempt to make things more accessible to users.

Similarly, they've built a lot of new technology and widely adopted a lot of very library specific technologies, things that enable them to share records with one another to reduce their work efforts and to have a standard for self check.

Circulation transactions for the Self check machines and then more more recent protocols for things like resolving article requests automatically for embedding citations and for even offering up different metadata representations.

So, given that we have a mission of satisfying a broad range of user queries, helping people achieve research results that we are invested in creating machine readable metadata that we have a broad culture that is oriented towards sharing and openness, transparency is important to libraries and that we have a demonstrated history of being early adopters of technology and creating new technology.
You would think that we would be all over the semantic web.
Not the case sadly.
We have a barrier.
We have a number of barriers.
One is that we are very much in the strings, not things world machine readable.
Cataloging is readable by machines, but it is really oriented towards tape transmission and storage.
The communication that goes on in Mark Records.

As you can see in the this example down here is that we have a publication date 2013, but the cataloger who entered this put it in square brackets because that number was not found on the title page of the book that they were looking at.
They found the information about the publication date somewhere else, so unfortunately that's not necessarily a standardized convention that we can accurately.
Read and parse by machines.
It's not an easy thing to do.
It is supposed to mean something to the humans that read it on the other end.

One would argue that perhaps most patrons wouldn't make any sort of a difference between that anyways, but that's the kind of textual annotation that we have mixed in with the really good data that we want to have access to in the state of Mark records today.

We also had a call to arms in 2011 when Ed Summers, who's really a linchpin connector between the library in the linked Data Worlds, wrote that libraries have been really good about creating and adopting technologies, but they've been very technology specific technologies.
Sorry, library technology, specific technologies.
And that the greater world of the web, the semantic web things like RDF a things.
Things like Sitemaps have passed libraries by and that libraries need to catch up because we've been in some ways leapfrog by generation of technology.
And yet another barrier is proprietary library software.
In most cases, the vendors are not interested in adding enhancements, particularly if they're not enhancements that give them a direct return on investment.
And it's hard for customers to motivate them.

They can usually vote put together votes, but the vendors are not beholden to actually making any changes and the customers themselves who may be interested in trying to make the changes on their on their own behalf have problems.
Most of the systems that are available still don't have persistent ur eyes, which is a basic requirement for really making progress on the semantic web.
API access is restricted in one of the major cases.
Most customers resort to screen scraping their own catalogs to get the data out of the system that they in theory own.
Templating systems that are deployed by proprietary library systems typically are not standardized, so you invest the effort.
The cognitive overload's Steven Staub was talking about in his keynote.
Yes, yesterday to learn a new tool, and that effort is thrown away once you move to a different employment situation or you move to a different technology.
And in talking about public and academic libraries, there's not a whole lot of resource is to actually put towards the problem in the 1st place, so that also is a barrier.
So I don't want to be all doom and gloom.
We have had great success, particularly in the European fields with things like the Swedish Union catalogue, the German National Library is done outstanding work.
Bibliotheque Nationale de France, which presented last year about their work in creating RDF accessible versions of their catalog and OC else.
However, you'll notice that all of these things have something in common, their national scale or bigger, which means that they also have more resources than your typical public.
Academic library they have political capital and will to make changes to workflows that may not be possible in smaller libraries.
Andsoschema.org, as we're all familiar with, offers a very pragmatic reason for joining Link data.
The SCO carrot gets dangled in front of of institutions and users, so you would think that American academic libraries would have jumped on board.
So Jason Ranallo from North Carolina State University when he analyzed the 2012 common crawl results one year after schema.org was released.
Found that American academic libraries had fewer than 10,000 instances separate instances in the entirity of all of the library websites that he looked at.
That wasn't just catalogs.
That was everything, so not so much pick up there.
So what do we do?
We change the things that we can.
So what I worked on was teaching open source library systems to express structured data in RDF A to do it by default.
And use a schema.org vocabulary.
So we've got some advantages with open source library systems.
One is that their native to the web, so persistent ur eyes not a problem.
We've got a great starting base with that.

They have communities that are receptive to new technology and advances and they understand the advantage of linked data so you can make code contributions and actually have a change take place and they build on standard components.
So I talked.
Did three separate implementations.

I wanted to make sure that the approach is taking was going to be generally applicable, so we used KOA, Evergreen and view find, all of which been around for 10 or well, almost 10 years or more and estimating the number of instances that exist is very difficult with open source software.
Subtopics of separate papers, but we can generalize.
We know that there are self reported numbers of 2500 in the case of KOA, so the self reported numbers are the lowest end.
And then there are other estimates that to estimate much higher.
And similarly it's very difficult 'cause it's self reporting only to know how many records exist in every one of these instances.
So we're talking between 10,000 for a small Public Library or specialized library up to a million or more for academic libraries.
Our our institution runs a consortial catalog for three separate universities, and we have around 2 million records in our Evergreen instance.
Just give you an idea of the scope.

During this process, because we're using schema.org, we were able to identify gaps in the schema.org vocabulary where we were necessary for extensions for bibliographic purposes, and will work both with the web schemas group directly using primarily the public vocabs mailing list as well as the schema Bib X W3C Community Group.

And I was able to use KOA view, find an Evergreen as reference systems for the implementations of the ideas that the group is talking about, because quite often we would have discussions and it was not known whether things are going to be feasible until it's actually put in practice, which was a nice change from the proprietary participant proprietary software participant in our group, who had said no, we have no plans of actually implementing anything.
We're just going to wait and see how it all shakes out.
Scrape.
So my approach very simply.
Was to map the mark types to schema.org types that I could find, so it was very easy to get high confidence in bookmap in music album.
And then everything else had to fall back to creative work you would expect, especially with public libraries.
Perhaps that there would be DVD's, VCR, video recordings and.
The problem is that Mark 21 really hampers some of the efforts because it's overly complex, but not not, not yet specific enough in some cases.
So we get projected medium video recording electronic, but we don't get.
Is this a movie or a TV series that we're talking about?

You have to cross reference with subject headings in some cases to be able to find out whether you're talking about the TV series, but given that I was applying this to general library systems, I could not guarantee that we would have Library of Congress subject headings or local.
Subject headings, so I left that as A to do.
And then I Maps the record elements to schema.org properties again, because all of the bibliographic types that we are focusing on derived from creative work.
It was easiest to start by focusing on the creative work properties, of which there are many in schema.org, and then look at the specializations that were necessary for things like map or 4.
Music album and that was easy enough to do and for the most part this was looking at using Xpath.
We had serialized Mark as XML.
Use X path to extract the elements that we wanted and then clean it up to remove annotations like the trailing paperback that would appear after ISBN's for example.
Then we link the resource is to the described object.

So that means that if we had three copies of say, a given book or a given DVD in the library, we create each one of those is a good relations offer and we would treat the book or creative work as a product and multi type it.

So that would enable us to piggyback on what search engine's would see as a product offer without having to create our own library specific gap vocabulary, which would be unlikely to be adopted anyways, being realistic.
So we may be able to piggyback on that for a search engine.
This is.

And then I was also able to describe the libraries themselves using linked dataschema.org provides a library type which inherits from organization which gives us the ability to give geographic information contact information, operating hours, all of which again will be useful from the perspective of a search engine attempting to supply a user with a copy of a desired resource, not knowing whether that offer is going to be a borrowing offer or a sale for 1399.
Only Evergreen implements that today because it's the only one that contains all that information ready at hand.
But there was certainly interest expressed by the other library systems in adopting.
That's a similar approach.
So just to show how the schema.org DFA pops up.
Up at the top you can see the title just Maps very simply to a multi typed book product and then the title itself becomes the schema name.
We take the author.
You can have multiple authors or contributors or editors and do some fine grained resolution of that.
But we create entities rather than just having the schema.org cop out of having string literal literals for every property value.
So we have a person entity that we linked to.
And we can separate the birth date and the death date.
Again, having to use regular expressions isn't that fun.
We have multiple ISBN's pop up again cleaned up via regular expression.
And we create a separate organization for the publisher.
And we also link off to the publishing date as you'll notice it's not clean in all cases.
We still pull in the period at the end.
There's punctuation that slides through.
Situation can be tricky, but and then here's the offer, so the copy that's available results in a schema offer using good relations vocabulary.
Our availability is shown as being in stock.
We've given a link that goes to the library information so that intelligent agent can figure out the operating hours and location.
And then that's the kind of information that'll get from the library structured data if it goes to resolve that.
So I did successfully implement this.
There's on hand around 10:10 types that are being expressed in these three systems today, with about 37 schema.org properties.

All of the projects happily accepted the code, and these have all been released as a main release, so going forward, any library that has adopted these open source library systems and upgrades to the latest release for support or maintenance purposes is also going to start publishing link data on the web thanks to these enhancements.
Schema.org was able to express the library resource is satisfactorily.
For our purposes.
There was one exception that we noted in the schema Becks for periodicals where we put forward a proposal which is moving forward.

And one of the things that is able to do was instead of having to dump massive amounts of Mark records and ship them to a central location on a periodic basis to create a union catalog, I was able to make use of Google Custom search engine structured data support to create a union catalog effectively in 5 minutes just by dropping in the URLs as interested in for the various libraries that want to participate, which is a world of difference from the very manually intensive approach that libraries typically adopt today.
And so roughly 5000 libraries.
Perhaps fewer will be publishing link data very shortly.

So I believe that the contributions I've made is that libraries are actually starting to appear, small libraries, small public and academic libraries, not national scope libraries are now starting to appear on the semantic Web.
We do have patterns that other libraries delivery systems can adopt for their own purposes, and the code is available as well.
In working with good relations, we revise the definitions of the properties to be noncommercial in nature.

So it would be inclusive of commercial and non commercial institutions and schema.org and I believe Martin said you were going to potentially right, which is fantastic and we have proposed extensions to deal with periodicals that have been put forward to schema.org.

So I can say that schema.org has been in the RDF schema.org approach has been successful as successful experiment and that for libraries in general, the lessons that we can take away is that at summer is right.
Are DFA Insight Maps do offer a viable alternative to legacy library protocols and standards, so with that I'll put it up for questions.
